Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Sensing as a Service - Architectures for Closed-Loop Sensor Network Virtualization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to demonstrate new cyber-physical architectures that allow the sharing of closed-loop sensor networks among multiple applications through the dynamic allocation of sensing, networking, and computing resources. The sharing of sensor network infrastructures makes the provision of data more cost efficient and leads to virtual private sensor network (VPSN) architectures that can dramatically increase the number of sensor networks available for public use. These cyber infrastructures support a paradigm, called Sensing as a Service, in which users can obtain sensing and computational resources to generate the required data for their sensing applications. The challenge in sharing closed-loop sensor networks is that one application's actuation request might interfere with another's request. To address this challenge the VPSN architectures are comprised of three components: 1) a sensor virtualization layer that ensures that users obtain timely access to sensor data when requested and isolates their requests from others' through the creation of appropriate scheduling algorithms; 2) a computation virtualization layer that enables the allocation of computational resources for real-time data intensive applications which is closely tied to the sensor virtualization layer; 3) a virtualization toolkit that supports application developers in their efforts to build applications for virtualized, closed-loop sensor networks.

The sharing of closed-loop sensor networks leads to substantial savings on infrastructure and maintenance costs. The proposed VPSN architectures enable users to create their own applications without having detailed knowledge of sensing technologies and allows them to focus on the development of applications. VPSNs will contribute to the creation of a nationwide, shared sensing cyber infrastructure, which will provide critical information for public safety and security. VPSNs will also help to revolutionize the way undergraduate and graduate students from many disciplines perform research. Students will be shielded from some of the complexities of sensor networks and allowed to focus on their core research. To prepare students from the Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) department at the University of Massachusetts to perform this kind of research, new classes in the area of Integrative Systems Engineering and Sensor Network Virtualization will be offered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to demonstrate that closed-loop sensor networks can be shared between different applications. To achieve this goal this project developed and implemented mechanisms and architectures that enable the dynamic allocation of sensing, networking, and compute resources. Being able to share sensor network infrastructures among different applications makes the provisioning of data more cost efficient since the investment in infrastructure is significantly reduced. In addition, virtualized sensor network architectures allow users to create their own applications without the need for in-depth knowledge of sensing technologies.  This project focused on three major activities to build an end-to-end architecture for sensor network virtualization: scheduling for sensor virtualization, computational virtualization support for applications that process sensor data, and the application of network virtualization to isolate traffic from different applications.

On the subject of sensor virtualization, initial results on a Time-Division Multiple Access (TDMA) approach indicated that access control schemes enable sensor/actuator virtualization and, thus, allow the isolated sharing of such resources. Further analyzing the results led us to the development of an advanced approach called Data-Sharing Enabled Scheduling (DSES) that shares sensor data across isolated applications.  In the case of DSES priority can be given to certain application (e.g., a tornado tracking application during a severe weather outbreak), while other applications can still use the sensors with limited utility. An analysis based on operational sensor network data showed the potential of sharing of closed-loop sensor networks with the downside that the overall utility is reduced if compared to individual, dedicated networks. The results show that there is a clear trade-off between utility and cost where applications can share a network. To further optimize the DSES approach, we introduced batch processing and reordering of requests to maximize the number of sensing request overlaps in and advanced version of DSES (ADSES). Though the total utility and average cost/applications is almost the same as in DSES, the utility is uniformly distributed across all the applications in ADSES. Also, the ADSES design and implementation is better aligned with the operations of real sensor network systems.

In terms of applications that process sensor data and make use of virtualized computation, we demonstrated how flood forecasting applications can be executed significantly faster in a cloud computing environment that uses parallel processing. The flood forecast application is using Quantitative Precipitation Estimation (QPE) produced by a network of X-band radars. Based on the QPE data and the provision of the virtualized, on-demand compute resources, 1 minute – 250 m resolution flood forecasts can be provided. Providing the public and emergency managers with such high-resolution data (in space and time) is important since more precise flood warnings can be issued in a timely manner.

Especially during severe weather events mobile traffic volume is increasing rapidly, pressuring the underlying infrastructure to quickly increase its capacity. This increase in traffic volume is due to the public’s interest in the event and related warnings but also their eagerness to find out if family and friends are safe. Device-to-Device communication has been long recognized as a means to offload traffic from the infrastructure-based network; however, the host-oriented model of the TCP/IP-based Internet poses challenges to this communication pattern. Our work addressed this issue by proposing a scheme that uses a data-centric model to fetch contents from nearby peers while increasing the resiliency of the network in cases of outages and disasters. An evaluation of our approach has shown that up to 51.7% of traffic can be offloaded from the backhaul network when our peer-to-peer approach is applied. With this approach spikes in traffic in backhaul networks can be significantly reduced while users still receive important data in a timely fashion.

To enable end-to-end data-centric communication, we developed a network architecture that supports the operation of different network protocol stacks on top of the same physical network infrastructure. Based on this architecture IP and data-centric based communications can be performed in parallel on the same network.

This project supported two master of science and one PhD student. These graduate students benefited from having the opportunity to perform research in the area of cyberphysical systems. Beyond the typical research opportunities for graduate students, this project allowed the students to evaluate architectures that will be developed on actual sensors and sensor networks. Through our close relationship with the Engineering Research Center for Collaborative Adaptive Sensing of the Atmosphere, the students had the opportunity to present their work to CASA partners from government organizations and industry.
